edu.csupomona.cs.cs141.thehouse

Class GameEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.csupomona.cs.cs141.thehouse.GameEngine

  • public class GameEngine
extends java.lang.Object
    GameEngine is where almost everything from the other classes contribute to the game. The GameEngine takes user commands from UserInterface, checks with Player, and then performs the tasks. It is also where the Enemy class performs the actions it decides. GameEngine updates the Grid and retrieves positions from it. GameEngine also checks to see if the Player has picked up any power-ups or if they have ammo left.
    Author:
    Andrew Nipp, Andrew Niklas, Ben Nickerson, Kurt Newcomd, Dylan Nguyen

      • choice

        private java.lang.String choice
        This field holds the choice of the user. There are xx potential values for the user to select: left, right, up, down, shoot, save, exit

        private java.lang.String lookDirection
        This field holds the choice of direction for which the user will "look" before each turn. There are four directions: left, right, up, down

    • Constructor Detail

      • GameEngine

        public GameEngine()
        The default constructor for GameEngine. It instantiates all of the other objects: UserInterface, File_Handler, Player, Grid, and Sound. It then calls Grid.setUpGrid() to populate it and sets the moves to 0.

    • Method Detail

      • newGame

        public void newGame()
        This constructor is used whenever the user beats the game and starts a new one. It follows the same instantiation as the initial constructor, but also sets all boolean values to false.

      • startGame

        public void startGame()
        This method simply calls mainMenuSelect(), but exists to be called from Main

      • gameLoop

        public void gameLoop()
        The main loop of the game, this is where all the checks and actions go. The loop is finished once gameOver is set to be true either from finding the briefcase, the player dying, or the user quitting.

      • getNewGameStart

        public boolean getNewGameStart()
        This method will return the boolean newGameStart to whatever calls it
        Returns:
        - boolean newGameStart

      • objectCheck

        public void objectCheck()
        This method checks every turn to see if there is an object wherever the Player moved. It does this by comparing the Player.get_yPosition() and Player.get_xPosition() to the location of the GameObjects. Each power up has a different set of methods that it will call when activated, but all of them call Sound.foundPowerup().

      • mainMenuSelect

        public void mainMenuSelect()
        This method is called after UserInterface.mainMenu() prints the menu. It uses a switch statement to check each potential command, and a do-while loop to ensure that proper input is received. When default is used, the code repeats, otherwise a specific command is called: Specifically, "new" starts a new game , "continue" continues the game from its last state , "rules" calls UserInterface.rules() , "options" calls UserInterface.options() , "exit" exits the program

      • turnSelect1

        public void turnSelect1()
        This method is the top menu during the beginning of each round. It calls UserInterface.turnSelect1() to print out the menu, then asks for input. The input is then run through a switch statement. There are 8 cases for the statement: "new" - calls newGame() and starts over again; "dev" - calls up the dev menu, which basically allows the user to enter god mode; "mute" - sets musicOn to false and calls Sound.stopBackgroundLoop(); "look" - calls up UserInterface.lookDirections() and moves the user to that menu; "move" - calls up UserInterface.moveTurn() and allows the user to select a direction; "shoot" - calls up UserInterface.shootTurn() and allows the user to select a direction; "options" - calls up UserInterface.options() and allows the user to make a selection before returning to the game; "exit" - exits the game; Finally, the default case will simply restart the do-while loop and call UserInterface.invalidCMD().

      • turnSelect2

        public void turnSelect2()
        This method is the top menu during the beginning of each round specifically after the look function has been used. It calls UserInterface.turnSelect2() to print out the menu, then asks for input. The input is then run through a switch statement. There are 8 cases for the statement: "new" - calls newGame() and starts over again; "dev" - calls up the dev menu, which basically allows the user to enter god mode; "mute" - sets musicOn to false and calls Sound.stopBackgroundLoop(); "move" - calls up UserInterface.moveTurn() and allows the user to select a direction; "shoot" - calls up UserInterface.shootTurn() and allows the user to select a direction; "options" - calls up UserInterface.options() and allows the user to make a selection before returning to the game; "exit" - exits the game; Finally, the default case will simply restart the do-while loop and call UserInterface.invalidCMD().

      • devMenu

        public void devMenu(java.lang.String cmd)
        This method is called whenever "dev" is selected in one of the turnSelects. It will ask for a new input and send that input to this method as a parameter. Dev mode is not very robust since it is specifically used by the developers, therefore it can crash the game if someone does not know what they are doing. There are 4 main functions: "check" - asks for input for the (x, y) coordinates and checks to see if an Enemy is present "show" - shows all objects on the Grid "hide" - hides all objects on the Grid "on/off" - turns dev mode (god mode) on. Shows all objects and gives infinite ammo and shield.
        Parameters:
        cmd - - String containing the value of one of the cases in the switch statement.

      • setOption

        public void setOption()
        This method deals with input received after it calls UserInterface.options(). It can be called at any point during a game and has 5 functions: "debug" - turns on debug mode; "save" - saves the game's state by calling File_Handler.fileLander(String, Grid, Player); "new" - starts a new game; "mute" mutes the music; "exit" - exits the game; Finally, default will call itself to essentially loop the method after printing UserInterface.invalidCMD()

      • setDebug

        public void setDebug()
        This method is called when debug is selected from the options menus. It only has one function, to turn debug on/off. It will print a message displaying verification of the user's selection.

      • movePlayerForTurn

        public void movePlayerForTurn()
        This method will move the Player by calling Player.movePlayer(String) and Grid.rePopulateGrid(Player) . It then sets didPlayerTakeTurn to true and moves on.

      • debugMode

        public void debugMode(boolean on)
        This method activates debug mode. Basically it runs through all of the visibilities in Grid and sets them to true. It then adds over 9000 to both the ammo supply and shield turns. If boolean on is false it will do the opposite, but will not remove any bullets or shield turns. This mode is not recommended while playing the game seriously.
        Parameters:
        on - - boolean containing a value that will activate or deactivate debug mode.

      • playerDefaultVision

        public void playerDefaultVision()
        This method gives the Player sight in the direction that they are looking. It is assumed that the Player is looking in the direction that they last moved or looked. Its default case assumes the Player is looking up at spawn.

      • removeDefaultVision

        public void removeDefaultVision()
        This method is needed to ensure that the square that was visible before the Player moves or\ looks is set back to hidden.

      • getMoves

        public int getMoves()
        This method will pass moves to whatever calls it
        Returns:
        - int moves

      • setM

        public void setM(int m)
        This method will set m to whatever is passed in as an int in the parameter.
        Parameters:
        m - - int containing the intended value for m
